content: The Act of 1994 is titled the "Urban Recreation and At-Risk Youth Act" and includes findings related to the act. The Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 is amended to address the decline in urban park and recreation facilities due to underfunding of Federal grant programs. The Act acknowledges the impact on the quality of life in urban areas and the increase in violent crime among youth in deteriorating urban neighborhoods. The Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 is amended to address the decline in urban park and recreation facilities due to underfunding of Federal grant programs. It recognizes the impact on the quality of life in urban areas and the increase in violent crime among youth. Accessible recreational facilities and urban sport programs are effective in preventing crime and teaching important values to young people. The purpose of the assistance is to improve recreation facilities and expand services in urban areas with high crime rates, deter crime by providing more recreation opportunities for at-risk youth, increase security in urban parks, and promote collaboration between local agencies involved in parks, law enforcement, youth services, and the juvenile justice system. The Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 is amended to include at-risk youth recreation grants for programs in high-crime neighborhoods, focusing on providing constructive alternatives to youth at risk for criminal behavior. Rehabilitation grants for youthful offenders can be used to improve security in urban parks by providing lighting, emergency phones, or other capital improvements. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTION. Section 1005(c) of the Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 is amended to prioritize at-risk youth recreation grants based on criteria such as targeting youth at risk of violence and crime, teaching important values and life skills, and offering tutoring, mentoring, and counseling in addition to recreation opportunities. The Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 is amended to prioritize at-risk youth recreation grants based on criteria such as targeting youth at risk of violence and crime, teaching important values and life skills, and offering tutoring, mentoring, and counseling in addition to recreation opportunities. Programs must offer services during late night or other nonschool hours, demonstrate collaboration between various agencies and organizations, leverage public or private investments, and show potential for continuation with non-Federal funds or as models for other communities. SEC. 6 amends the Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 to require local governments to incorporate reducing crime and juvenile delinquency in their 5-year action program to be eligible for 'at-risk youth recreation grants'. The plan should also address coordination with law enforcement, juvenile corrections, and youth social service agencies. SEC. 7 includes miscellaneous and technical amendments. SEC. 7 of the Urban Park and Recreation Recovery Act of 1978 includes miscellaneous and technical amendments related to program support and extension. The amendment limits the use of funds for program support to 25 percent for any local government and removes the requirement for a five-year period for certain provisions.
